title: How to Know Some Kitchen Basics

steps.headline: Look for cookbooks which contain basic and simple recipes for you to practice and have fun preparing.
steps.description: Focus on one recipe at a time and give yourself enough time to improve your cooking.

steps.headline: Learn how to use basil.
Know where, and how, to store your spices.
steps.description: Your spices should be stored in any area that is dark and cool. Storing spices in lighted areas or warm areas can reduce their length of freshness. Try to find a cool, dark cupboard if you want to increase the flavor and lifespan of your favorite spices. If you use fresh spices, your food will taste better.

steps.headline: Clean your microwave with a lemon.
Use colorful foods in your meal preparation.
steps.description: Meals that are full of color are healthy and visually stunning. Some colorful garnishes you can add to your meals include cherry tomatoes, cilantro, parsley and carrot curls. Do a little experimentation with different foods and colors to produce dishes that are both awe inspiring and appetizing.

steps.headline: If you are making a salad ahead of time, put some thought into how you layer its ingredients.
steps.description: Tomatoes and other juicy ingredients should be on the bottom layer and lettuce along with any other ingredients which might wilt or get soggy should be on the top.

steps.headline: You should know a few things before you cook anything on a skewer.
steps.description: Metal skewers will work better if they are twisted or squared.

steps.headline: There are a few ways to heat up tortillas.
steps.description:
One of the ways is to warm an oven up to 350 °F (177 °C), and then place the tortilla right on the oven rack until it reaches the crispness you desire. You can also crisp your tortilla on the gas burner of your stove-top. Just turn the flame on low and place the tortilla on the burner above the flame. Watch it carefully! It only takes a moment! A hot, fresh, crunchy tortilla is within reach when these simple techniques are used. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/02\/Know-Some-Kitchen-Basics-Step-8Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Know-Some-Kitchen-Basics-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/02\/Know-Some-Kitchen-Basics-Step-8Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Know-Some-Kitchen-Basics-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

steps.headline: Make sure you use silicone or rubber utensils if you cook with nonstick pans.
steps.description: Hard utensils like wood or metal can scratch your cookware and the coatings on them that provide that non stick surface. This doesn't taste great, and can also be dangerous.

steps.headline: Apply these concepts, and try thinking of some of your own, too!
steps.description: Make meals that will relax you and that you can enjoy and your family will appreciate them as well. Learning to cook can help you to improve your diet, and it can also enhance your quality of life. The kitchen should be the centerpiece of your home.
